Recruitment.Definition: Measures the average time taken to fill a vacant position.
Recruitment.Formula: Total Days to Hire / Number of Hires
Recruitment.Example: 100 days to hire 5 people -> Time to Hire = 20 days
Recruitment.Remark: Shorter times indicate a more efficient hiring process.

Recruitment.Definition: Tracks the average cost incurred to hire a new employee.
Recruitment.Formula: Total Recruitment Cost / Number of Hires
Recruitment.Example: $50,000 recruitment cost, 10 hires -> Cost per Hire = $5,000
Recruitment.Remark: Lower costs indicate a more efficient recruitment process.

Recruitment.Definition: Measures the percentage of job offers that are accepted by candidates.
Recruitment.Formula: (Number of Offers Accepted / Total Offers Made) * 100
Recruitment.Example: 30 offers accepted out of 40 -> Acceptance Rate = 75%
Recruitment.Remark: High acceptance rates indicate attractive job offers.

Recruitment.Traduction: Taux de Rétention des Nouveaux Employés
Recruitment.Definition: Tracks the percentage of new hires who stay with the company for a specified period.
Recruitment.Formula: (Number of New Hires Retained / Total New Hires) * 100
Recruitment.Example: 45 out of 50 new hires retained -> Retention Rate = 90%
Recruitment.Remark: High retention rates indicate successful onboarding.

Recruitment.Definition: Measures the average number of qualified candidates interviewed for each hire.
Recruitment.Formula: Total Qualified Candidates / Number of Hires
Recruitment.Example: 40 qualified candidates for 10 hires -> 4 candidates per hire
Recruitment.Remark: Fewer candidates per hire indicate an efficient recruitment process.

Employee Satisfaction.Definition: Measures overall employee satisfaction based on survey results.
Employee Satisfaction.Remark: Higher scores indicate higher satisfaction levels.

Employee Satisfaction.Definition: Measures employee loyalty and their likelihood to recommend the company as a good place to work.
Employee Satisfaction.Remark: Higher scores indicate more loyal employees.

Employee Satisfaction.Definition: Measures the rate at which employees leave the company within a given period.
Employee Satisfaction.Formula: (Number of Leavers / Average Number of Employees) * 100
Employee Satisfaction.Remark: Lower rates indicate better employee retention.

Employee Satisfaction.Definition: Tracks the percentage of workdays missed due to employee absence.
Measures the percentage of job openings filled by internal candidates.
Employee Satisfaction.Example: 15 internal promotions, 20 total promotions -> Internal Promotion Rate = 75%
Employee Satisfaction.Remark: Higher rates indicate good career development opportunities.

Training and Development.Definition: Measures the average number of training hours provided per employee.
Training and Development.Example: 1,000 training hours, 50 employees -> Training Hours per Employee = 20
Training and Development.Remark: More training hours indicate greater investment in development.

Training and Development.Definition: Measures the percentage of training programs completed by employees.
Training and Development.Example: 45 completed programs, 50 total programs -> Completion Rate = 90%
Training and Development.Remark: High rates indicate effective training engagement.

Training and Development.Traduction: Taux de Plan de Développement des Employés
Training and Development.Definition: Measures the percentage of employees with active development plans.
Training and Development.Example: 40 employees with plans, 50 total employees -> Plan Rate = 80%
Training and Development.Remark: Higher rates indicate a focus on employee development.

Training and Development.Definition: Measures the improvement in employee performance following training.
Tracks the average monetary investment in training per employee.
Training and Development.Example: $50,000 training investment, 100 employees -> Investment per Employee = $500
Training and Development.Remark: Higher investments indicate a commitment to employee growth.
